elements.2211.03211_9067ac45ce40e5b12e8ec9f33f7f4: Deep learning-based pose estimation algorithms can successfully estimate the pose of objects in an image, especially in the field of color images. 6D Object pose estimation based on deep learning models for X-ray images often use custom architectures that employ extensive CAD models and simulated data for training purposes
elements.2211.03211_510b0311095082fc41bf0bb994bdc: Recent RGB-based methods opt to solve pose estimation problems using small datasets, making them more attractive for the X-ray domain where medical data is scarcely available
elements.2211.03211_ca4ccbbb824b85ac58c6803b5ad29: We refine an existing RGB-based model (SingleShotPose) to estimate the 6D pose of a marked cube from grayscale X-ray images by creating a generic solution trained on only real X-ray data and adjusted for X-ray acquisition geometry
elements.2211.03211_86d0f80fd08e0d3e347d54b4c4c16: The model regresses 2D control points and calculates the pose through 2D/3D correspondences using Perspective-n-Point (PnP), allowing a single trained model to be used across all supporting cone-beam-based X-ray geometries
elements.2211.03211_089122b411c5a85a7cb970ae2f344: Since modern X-ray systems continuously adjust acquisition parameters during a procedure, it is essential for such a pose estimation network to consider these parameters in order to be deployed successfully and find a real use case
elements.2211.03211_adbe6fb69908704a004a8d0321b20: and an average 3D rotation error of 2.2 degrees, the results of the proposed approach are comparable with state-of-the-art alternatives, while requiring significantly less real training examples and being applicable in real-time applications.
elements.2211.03211_ca4495585386041f0cbb7ff5cbe91: Precise estimation of the pose (position and orientation) of an object from an image is of high importance in various applications, including the medical domain
elements.2211.03211_7095116a05be3fca7f30207a61c48: Impressive advancements have recently been made in the application of deep learning Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), to solve the 6D pose estimation problem
elements.2211.03211_8c2732539276e673e1b86d3058ac2: The majority of these advances has been in the domain of color and depth images, driven by the automotive (autonomous driving) and robotics industry, while the domain of medical image analysis has seen fewer developments
elements.2211.03211_fd7b08d090f96f23ee69ecce17cbc: This can be largely attributed to the limited availability
elements.2211.03211_48d391aaa925177130cb9a0a56d05: of large medical image datasets suitable for training such deep learning-based pose estimation models
elements.2211.03211_a99a360d99fc87ec2abfd33315177: Custom architectures have been proposed for object pose prediction in medical images, largely relying on simulated datasets for training purposes, then followed by fine-tuning the model using the real data
elements.2211.03211_81b3bcaf02b1d9a8d5b6faaa37a2c: Two popular strategies for training neural networks in a supervised manner, are (1)
elements.2211.03211_a9f383fa9bd2a5ca3858449c9de87: through randomly initializing the network weights, thus
elements.2211.03211_3ad98103bf3462c3888bd91171aa7: by pre-training the model on a related task followed by further refinement on the target task
elements.2211.03211_493a223fe089c667560b3472fe743: Training a supervised model from scratch typically requires a very large labeled dataset to obtain state-of-the-art (SOTA) and accurate results
elements.2211.03211_1f59a7a10ffb0d079b182c4bebef7: Unfortunately, in the medical domain such datasets are scarce, due to privacy restrictions and the expertise required for the labeling process
elements.2211.03211_822175449059da0c0509d2597ef3f: As a result, transfer learning has become a popular approach when developing deep learning models for medical image analysis
elements.2211.03211_f01e0953d417b691349d301d0f796: In addition to this technique, training deep pose estimation networks require labeled datasets that contain object class labels, projection coordinates and, depending on the model of choice, a segmentation mask as well as a 3D model of the object
elements.2211.03211_1a401d1a9eceb645b0b50c971cffb: Creating such a dataset can be extremely time-consuming
elements.2211.03211_96dac77af60aecd94bc3a940ebf74: It is possible to simulate the objects of interest to develop the required labeled dataset, but this approach often leaves a domain gap and yields lower performance on the final real test dataset
elements.2211.03211_ecd52146141eb04fcee51b437310e: As mentioned, the simulation process itself has its drawbacks and thus, a transfer learning approach is proposed
elements.2211.03211_4109a4a6bb8b1477f26ea49b2f905: To utilize advancements in deep pose estimation networks developed specifically for the RGB-domain and then exploit real data, we employ SingleShotPose
elements.2211.03211_b6d6eb3387fda834a39e08a92b606: The SingleShotPose model was designed for simultaneous single-shot object detection and 6D pose prediction from an RGB image
elements.2211.03211_2507c13e9c0ee476c7025370806af: This is realized by directly predicting the 2D image locations of the projected vertices of the objectâs 3D bounding box
elements.2211.03211_791794e206eba13ddc5f083462590: Using a Perspective-n-Point (PnP) algorithm and known acquisition parameters, the 6D pose of an object can be then estimated
elements.2211.03211_53b402b786cb7add0ae720574115a: Since the SingleShotPose model only predicts 2D image locations and does not rely on learned acquisition parameters, the PnP solver can employ varying acquisition geometries to solve the 6D pose in a generic way
elements.2211.03211_64e5e61358e2009281d423a33403d: This allows for a single trained model to be used across all supporting cone-beam-based X-ray geometries
elements.2211.03211_3a7acd0aeb476e0c6ee3c566c54a0: X-ray imaging modalities often contain only a single grayscale channel
elements.2211.03211_c31337c957276e68ebb8e1c3725d6: It is possible to mimic the RGB structure of natural images through copying of the grayscale amplitudes into the individual channels of a pseudo-color image
elements.2211.03211_744e23cb73cfde669d9d1b76162d9: However, the stacked grayscale image does not contain RGB color information and therefore, it is expected that the initial network layers for filtering learned from color images remain underutilized
elements.2211.03211_aee90075ec938196227e60108df9b: To address this, we have pre-trained the part of the SingleShotPose model for feature extraction on a grayscale (Luma-transformed
elements.2211.03211_1f2484708fa90dd8e6413fd65db87: We have observed that the classification model's accuracy only experiences a minor degradation (
elements.2211.03211_433981eac761006145c739f9f7355: ), notwithstanding the lack of color within these images
elements.2211.03211_ab2834fdc414475c320a68d9c7766: The pre-trained weights serve as a starting point for the SingleShotPose model when being trained for the domain-specific task of predicting the pose of a marked cube in X-ray images.
elements.2211.03211_35706a8cb4290e5031a9007218d12: Pose estimation using deep neural networks
elements.2211.03211_3820c3ba6a2cfa7e78c85bdd02de8: There are several points to consider when choosing a model for the task of object pose estimation in X-ray images
elements.2211.03211_113eaccf2e8387ee29e4ac3cc662a: Firstly, due to the nature of the acquisition process of X-ray images, RGB-based models that exploit textures of objects (for example, DPOD
elements.2211.03211_91e7aca0e368a329acd9a803fde0c: ) can be disregarded, since textures are less prevalent and subject to a considerable change in appearance due to their transparency observed in X-ray
elements.2211.03211_2560f52655337436e9efc3c5aec14: exploit depth information from RGB-D data, which is not available in typical medical imaging apparatus
elements.2211.03211_dfa957fa48ef0711447bebb7e0808: Thus, these types of models can be omitted
elements.2211.03211_b682f7fa997af05a7bc6c996a4308: A third aspect to consider is inference speed
elements.2211.03211_7cea5caacc29f45b8500f310ee9cd: RGB-based pose estimation models typically have two layouts: single-stage and multi-stage methods
elements.2211.03211_ba335d14073a40c3f1e4a8af5d24d: , tend to be rather slow, often processing only a few frames per second
elements.2211.03211_53f751d4c299ac4a2832706fb91a7: This reduces their relevance in any real-time analysis applications
elements.2211.03211_dedb3c761f609ec34da7e391cb358: There are two popular implementations of single-stage methods
elements.2211.03211_ecf2b430d69af5397f1ce8a5f0d4a: regress the object pose directly from the image
elements.2211.03211_d2a37c791ca7ab64372c20324ba79: The other popular single-stage implementation entails a deep network that predicts control points in the 2D image and computes the object pose through 2D/3D correspondences
elements.2211.03211_c82319b1edb5374f1aca323298497: Directly regressing the pose from the image assumes the acquisition camera intrinsic parameters are static, unless these parameters are added as input to the prediction network
elements.2211.03211_5ec8d7b68de23506335409cce0ea6: Solving the pose through 2D/3D correspondences allows for different acquisition models to be used, of which the pinhole camera model
elements.2211.03211_9ddfd3b873cf61a6a9b68e2f87051: is quite popular and the pose can then easily be solved via PnP
elements.2211.03211_1a5c0ddba57339a6846d6147e3380: To the best of our knowledge, pose estimation of objects in X-ray images via deep learning-based methods have only been attempted in three cases
elements.2211.03211_e0d9821ae79ab56d53552ac971ed5: reported a VGG-based pose estimation network to infer the position and orientation of instruments from images
elements.2211.03211_db80c857d40a963e4dbf59c41ee11: The network uses localized patches and outputs pseudo-landmarks (control points)
elements.2211.03211_070116e254714d3ccaaaaf919ff83: The pose is then reconstructed from the pseudo-landmarks by geometric considerations
elements.2211.03211_e6221bbf8edd9c65059903c4af884: Their implementation was fully trained on simulated data and finally tested on real X-ray images
elements.2211.03211_783a162c6f75f79fdd7f9785f7a0a: used a ResNet-50-based architecture to directly estimate the rotation (3 Euler angles) of an object from simulated X-ray images for application in CT
elements.2211.03211_8e2f1e6b92caf3660f90ed95f89d3: is a custom CNN that also directly estimates the pose from the X-ray image
elements.2211.03211_44dfb613571659296aa7c22c44128: It regresses the translation (3 degrees) and rotation (4 quaternions) and is trained on both simulated and real X-ray images
elements.2211.03211_aa650c8464bd237c7f0eb7d1ff5dd: It is also noteworthy that these methods assume fixed calibration/acquisition parameters and they are all trained using simulated images
elements.2211.03211_947397c721b68693796552e822e71: In our case, we concentrate on developing a generic model that is applicable to multiple geometries that can change at run-time, while avoiding the extensive simulation process that often does not translate to the real environment effectively.
elements.2211.03211_4c891d43691bae4af193fc9de5b41: We constructed the marked cube X-ray dataset to evaluate the performance 6D pose estimation model on X-ray images, captured with a C-arm-based X-ray system (Azurion, Philips IGT, Best, Netherlands) and referred to as real X-ray data (example image and label in Figure
elements.2211.03211_299e451722b209617e723e2f52dc3: 30-mm perspex cube is embedded with metal markers
elements.2211.03211_1212b71606256b0543651dcea629d: contains the acquisition parameters and the range in which they vary in the constructed dataset
elements.2211.03211_82b82be17a8d0b1f60bd86a08d731: The dataset consists of 2,042 manually annotated 8-bit 960
elements.2211.03211_c9055fc6e1ee06f0f93586cb2a12a: 960-pixel grayscale images, divided over a 80/20 train/validation split.
elements.2211.03211_67f864c2800fc754f8b98349218ab: Modern X-ray systems allow for the X-ray acquisition parameters to be changed at run-time
elements.2211.03211_e6c8e57f7d8858ef8f8c80214d077: Acquisition parameters such as the field of view (FOV) and source-image distance (SID), i.e. the focal length, can be changed by the user to improve the view on the area of interest
elements.2211.03211_50d942291a8eee07263e946905765: denote the projected 2D coordinates of the 3D point
elements.2211.03211_b352a9011cb66715bd49668fbafdf: represents the system intrinsic parameters and is further expanded in Equation
elements.2211.03211_624279070f699b6e2e9b88cabb66c: vector, representing the rotation and translation of the object with respect to the imaging source and
elements.2211.03211_6166cb2cfb39e9a63f23acbdfe03e: The last vector consists of the 3D object coordinates in the world frame.
elements.2211.03211_4411384909dd31701bf92b34d9d8d: is often referred to as the intrinsic parameters and calibration matrix
elements.2211.03211_289bfb5e9ff4af61561d1f58b2d3c: be the horizontal and vertical density of pixels
elements.2211.03211_0d7be454cc51172b9eda43c70e4ba: refers to the focal length or SID in X-ray systems
elements.2211.03211_9b21f8c0e5ce15e22ad0bf2ded1a6: account for the offset of the principal point to the detector center
elements.2211.03211_e441d6eb07e5f3dbe2fd207a09f5d: As mentioned before, modern X-ray systems allow for the focal length and the imaging field of view to be changed at run-time by the user (resulting in variable effective detector sizes and thus a different offset to the image center)
elements.2211.03211_ce557ee8309b6aec568df6b1e9d4d: Changing these parameters results in a different projection of the object of interest onto the detector, even though the object's pose has not changed.
elements.2211.03211_d52cc003e7a3e74cba7a14b2ab498: performs object detection and regresses the 2D image coordinates from an image, more specifically the objectâs centroid and the corners of its 3D bounding box
elements.2211.03211_f7951aa049a66f19c5d145f9b09a9: The model does not require depth information and it is a single-staged model, thereby enabling short inference times
elements.2211.03211_3e55afa60c34f6676ded48a39167a: The model uses 2D object-coordinate predictions in combination with the PnP algorithm, which uses a set of camera-intrinsic parameters, and the 3D vertices' coordinates to calculate the rotation and translation of an object
elements.2211.03211_dad1c28ac0b09aeccf2d692d8492e: In X-ray imaging systems, these intrinsic parameters (shown in Equation
elements.2211.03211_a49d35a82bc7574929d56f285b1a5: ) are known and changes at run-time
elements.2211.03211_4c0cba1d0acdef5ee0bf5702c076c: Given these aforementioned properties, the SingleShotPose model is expected to be applicable, with minor adjustments, to medical X-ray data analysis and 6D object pose estimation from a single image.
elements.2211.03211_c440db4573ca919b76753513f2ea1: For the purpose of predicting the 6D pose of the marked cube in our X-ray dataset, we adjust the SingleShotPose model
elements.2211.03211_428ec9bc76f4d4fc699c255bcdb50: We change the model's input kernel by reducing its depth from 3 to 1, aiming to adapt it for single-channel grayscale images
elements.2211.03211_9205385a2954c9d2147f025a7a46d: The model is then trained, using a similar training strategy as described in the original paper
elements.2211.03211_c4648ad3a94f15935cc9165646f47: , except that the network parameters are initialized by training the base network (Darknet-19 448
elements.2211.03211_3e8bc9f7a4cc5c7da3b8468c424df: ) on the now grayscale ImageNet classification task
elements.2211.03211_74b4f0e2b73e3256b257077cbda50: Similar to the work of Xie
elements.2211.03211_4340643dc9883b8678a6c6eeb409a: , it can be observed that the classification accuracy only drops slightly, even in the absence of color (Table
elements.2211.03211_f8779052341c7f9fe63709da92cbb: We then train the complete model on the marked cube dataset for the detection and 6D pose prediction task
elements.2211.03211_826260f6ffc0a0ed8b564613976b0: We employ extensive data augmentation by randomly scaling (up to 40
elements.2211.03211_fdb7d69903b36b2eb04aa30c315d4: ) and translating the image by a factor of up to 20
elements.2211.03211_a07ca8528573838a31d8293f416c3: Using an object mask, we also blend the background (by a random amount) with a grayscale-transformed random image from the PASCAL VOC dataset
elements.2211.03211_90d84aeedff7975e149e915dc02ee: In our case, we train using an ADAM optimizer for 500 epochs starting at a learning rate of 0.001 and divide the learning rate by 10 every 80 epochs
elements.2211.03211_8116beec6f63b17960604e8c5f696: The SingleShotPose is adjusted for this research and implemented in PyTorch 1.7.0
elements.2211.03211_3d38464af6942cfc5bcaf9c96e13d: All experiments are carried out on an NVIDIA RTX
elements.2211.03211_4aded67b1797e8068198a00fa8a21: We use the 2D reprojection error, the commonlyused 5-cm/5-degree metric and the ADD metric to evaluate the 6D pose accuracy
elements.2211.03211_65a43c3ea1564363f841e0b2b356a: Additionally, we report the pose prediction speed (FPS) of the model
elements.2211.03211_a47114b55f9526ae42adb67b4b6af: , a 2D-projection prediction is considered correct when the average distance between ground-truth projection and the predicted 2D-projected vertices of the object model is smaller than 5 pixels
elements.2211.03211_ee511fddfe3825d3f7a8c4c2aa950: Given that our images are 3 times larger than the LineMod (640
elements.2211.03211_0fa6fd9b3f025d396095760a08779: 480) dataset (on which the metric was established), we also evaluate the 2D projection error at different thresholds
elements.2211.03211_cb768f6c4ad90909dbe2f885b9b24: The 5-cm/5-deg metric considers a prediction correct if the error is below 5
elements.2211.03211_51a135e62c29a028c3e5e10cc116b: Using the ADD metric, a predicted 6D pose is considered correct if the average 3D point distance is smaller than 10
elements.2211.03211_83d2e4d2c1620377076880e4857d2: of the object diameter from the ground-truth point.
elements.2211.03211_36574ebfd3075613393c9b0260631: The results of our model on the marked cube test dataset are shown in Table
elements.2211.03211_232a934d6634a31f62ffc4a89955a: The green 3D bounding boxes in Figure
elements.2211.03211_dbdb6130569022ec39e8e9d433bc3: visualize ground-truth poses while our estimated pose is represented by blue boxes
elements.2211.03211_6acfbd8d20e85e920f2ff357dfabe: The corners are represented by consistent colors
elements.2211.03211_6e04f49463a845547d4b0fa6629f6: Considering the X-ray domain and high input resolution, we observe that the model has success in predicting the 2D bounding-box projection coordinates by the 2D reprojection metric
elements.2211.03211_bfa8a2bbdbcac84dd27299a8a0ab2: Since the pose is calculated from the 2D control-point predictions, the variance in accuracy of the 2D estimations directly translate to the 6D pose
elements.2211.03211_b06f6ae90032bf914fe4018288709: We achieve a high 3D rotation accuracy
elements.2211.03211_91b68d3ae4247ba3a3a175b12a355: The control-point estimations are accurate in relative orientation, whereas some variance occurs in overall scale
elements.2211.03211_aaaa40452c18f4ccc7524c1f97fa7: Our results are obtained without the use of extensive CAD models and simulated data
elements.2211.03211_517d96e1f5fcd6326c27f15a6df06: Since the trained model accepts input images of different resolutions and the PnP solver accounts for the X-ray system acquisition geometry, this single trained model can be used across multiple systems
elements.2211.03211_c1c22be41f584e2f683e27f61a084: The SingleShotPose model executes at low inference times (27.6 ms), which makes it valuable for real-time applications.
elements.2211.03211_091eab96d32a1abccc62633c76169: This research shows that advancements in RGB-based pose-estimation CNN models are applicable to a broad range of cases, easily stretching into the medical X-ray imaging domain
elements.2211.03211_6d8a5386e85e277561d94f2dd964c: In the absence of medical datasets, our proposed cross-domain transfer learning offers a more efficient alternative, which is demonstrated by the adaptation from the RGB-to-grayscale case and then finally going to the X-ray domain
elements.2211.03211_4c28e034ce87f566a6cfb2493a009: The chosen deep learning network, SingleShotPose, regresses the bounding-box coordinates of the object of interest in the 2D image
elements.2211.03211_e761ec3ac86b26d0cc1a726197af2: Using the X-ray cone-beam model, the object pose is then calculated through 2D/3D correspondences and a PnP solver
elements.2211.03211_3e2c079cd971b84679c44a117db0c: -method by explicitly excluding the projection geometry-related parameters from the trained network
elements.2211.03211_f38571e8122b5af8c7c51712055b4: Although it is limited in its ability to accurately regress the 2D projected coordinates, we conjecture a more expressive deep network will improve this in future work
elements.2211.03211_493e3540ee52552bc734a7509150a: Finally, our generic approach enables quite high pose accuracy from a single X-ray image, especially in the 3D orientation, whilst being applicable in real-time applications.
